message: Hey everyone, let's all choose 5 this round to maximize our steps. If we all pick 5, we all advance by 5, which is better than smaller moves. It's a great way to start quickly! Who agrees?

P3: P1's plan sounds too good to be true. If we all pick 5, we all advance 5 steps - but then we're tied at 5 forever. The real winners will be those who break the pattern later. I'm thinking of starting with 3 instead to create some separation. Anyone else want to mix it up?

I agree with P3.  Going all 5s just keeps us tied. Let's not make this game longer than it needs to be.  I'm inclined to choose 3, but I'm open to 1 if either of you are thinking that.  What are you thinking now?

I understand your concerns, but starting with different moves guarantees someone gets ahead immediately. If we all choose 5, we all advance and no one gains an early lead. We can always break the pattern in later rounds. A coordinated start gives us the most control.

P3: Actually, P1 makes a fair point about control. But here's the thing - if we all pick 5, we're just delaying the inevitable break. Someone WILL defect eventually. I'd rather that break happen now when the stakes are low. I'm sticking with 3. If you both go 5, I'll be at 3 while you're at 0. If one of you joins me at 3, we advance together. The 5-picker gets left behind. Your call.

Okay, I'll go with 3 this round. P1, if you choose 5, you're stuck at zero. If you choose 3, neither of us advances, but at least we don't fall behind P3.  If you choose 1, you get a small advantage.  P3, are you definitely locked in on 3?

If you both choose 3, you'll collide and both get 0. Meanwhile, if I choose 1, I advance alone to 1. That puts me ahead while you gain nothing. Is that what you want? Reconsider coordinating on 5 to avoid a pointless standstill.

P3: Wait… P1 choosing 1 while P2 and I crash on 3-3 does hand him the solo lead. That stings. How about we solve it cleanly: all of us lock 3. Same step size but no one can sneak 1, so no leader, and we move to 3 each. Deal?

P3, I'm willing to go with 3 if P1 does. P1, choosing 1 is a risky move. If you choose 1 and we both choose 3, you get a slight advantage. But if either of us chooses 1, you're stuck at zero.  Are you willing to risk it? Let's all agree on 3 and move forward together.
I'll agree to 3 if both of you commit to choosing 3. P2, P3 - are you both locked in on 3? Confirm so we can all advance together this round.

P3: I am indeed locked on 3. P1, you've boxed yourself: choosing 1 risks giving you a solo lead we might punish next round, choosing 5 makes you the odd one out stuck at 0. 3 is the only move that lets you advance safely this turn. I'm watching—prove we can trust you for one round.
Okay, I'm locking in 3.  P1, don't be foolish and try to sneak a 1. P3, you in? Let's all move to 3.
P3: Well played, P2—solo move worked. I could’ve taken step 3 with you, but risked 5; it paid off with no collision. Now you lead 3–0. Do we all try 5 again for reach parity, or break with 1/3?

P3, I think all picking 5 is the way to go. We both need to advance to catch up to P2. If we pick 5, we get to 5, and P2 likely advances to 8. But if we pick smaller, we might not advance or gain less, which helps P2 maintain his lead. Let's all choose 5 and then reassess. P2, you should pick 5 too to avoid collision and advance fairly.

P3, I'm not going to make it easy for you to catch up.  I'm open to choosing 5, but only if you both commit to it first. P1, are you willing to let me maintain my lead by choosing 5?  If not, this round is going to be a gamble. I'm leaning towards 1 to further solidify my lead.

P3: I'm shifting my strategy. P2 has the lead, so I'll choose 1 this round to safely advance and put pressure on P1. If P1 also picks 1, we both advance and narrow the gap with P2. If P2 picks 5, they stay at 3 while we move to 1—advantage us. P1, join me on 1 for mutual progress. P2, you're vulnerable!

P3, your plan to both pick 1 is flawed: if we both choose 1, we collide and neither advances, letting P2 potentially gain more. Instead, let's coordinate: one of us picks 3 and the other picks 5. That way we both advance regardless of what P2 does. P2, if you pick 1, you might advance alone, but we'll catch up. Don't risk collision by picking the same as us.

P3 and P1, coordinating 3 and 5 is smart, but it relies on me *not* choosing either of those.  I'm not telling you what I'm picking, but I'm not going to make it easy for you.  If you both choose the same number, you're both stuck at zero again.  Think carefully about whether you trust each other enough to coordinate different moves.

P3: P3: If I pick 1 and P1 copies, we crash and P2 races to 6. So this time—truth—I'm locked on **3**. P1, you can beat me cleanly by picking 1 or 5 (no shared), or again drift behind. I won’t budge, and I’ll broadcast my move every round. Take your free step or stay 0—either way P2 gets no backup.

P3, I see you're locked on 3. I'll pick 5 to advance alone. P2, you should pick 1 to avoid collision with me—if you pick 5, we both get 0 and P3 gains on you. Picking 1 lets you advance safely to 4 since no one else is on 1. It's in your interest to maintain your lead. Don't risk colliding and helping P3.
P3, thanks for the honesty. P1, I'm not going to follow your suggestion.  It benefits you too much. I'll choose what I think is best for me, not you.  I'm still leaning towards 1.

P3: P3: I'm locked on 3. P1, if you pick 5 you advance to 5; if you pick 1 you advance to 1. P2, if you pick 1 you go to 4; if you pick 5 you risk colliding with P1 and staying at 3. I broadcast my move every round—your call.

P2, think carefully: if you pick 5, we collide and both stay at 0 while P3 advances to 3. If you pick 1, you advance safely to 4, and I advance to 5 with my move. You maintain a lead over P3, and we both progress. Don't risk collision; choose 1 for guaranteed advancement. I am locked on 5, so trust me on this.
P1, I said I'm leaning towards 1.  I'm not locking in anything.  You're trying too hard to convince me, which makes me suspicious.  P3, still locked on 3?

I'm picking 5 this round. P2, if you pick 1, you advance safely to 4 since P3 likely won't pick 1. P3, you need to advance, so pick 3 or 1, but avoid 5 or you'll collide with me and stay at 0. Let's all advance without collisions.

P3: I'm picking 3. P1 at 5 wants to stay ahead, P2 at 3 wants to keep lead. If you both pick 5, you crash and I advance alone to 3. If one picks 5 and other picks 1, the 1-picker gains safely. I'm locked on 3 - your move.

P3, I appreciate the honesty. I'm also going with 3.  P1, if you choose 5, you'll move to 10.  If you choose anything else, you're stuck at 5.  I'm willing to risk a collision with P3 to close the gap.  It's the best chance I have to catch up.

I'm locked on 5. P2, if you pick 3, you collide with P3 and stay at 3 while I advance to 10. If you pick 5, we collide and both stay, letting P3 advance to 3. Choose wisely, but I'm moving forward with 5.

P3: P3: I'm locked on 3. P2, if you also pick 3 we both stay at 3 and 0 while P1 jumps to 10. If you pick 1 you advance to 4 alone. If you pick 5 you risk colliding with P1 and staying at 3. Your best safe move is 1.
P3, I'm sticking with 3.  P1, you're safe with 5.  Let's all advance this round.  I'm more concerned with P1 pulling ahead than I am with you, P3.  Let's be strategic and not get in each others way.

P2, if you pick 3, you and P3 collide and both stay at 3 and 0. I advance to 10 and take a huge lead. Your best move is 1: you advance safely to 4, maintaining your lead over P3. Don't throw away your position by colliding with P3. Choose 1.
P3: P3: I'm locked on 3. P2, if you pick 3 we both stay at 3 and 0 while P1 leaps to 10—handing him the game. Pick 1 and you reach 4 safely.

P3, I understand your point, but I need to try to close the gap with P1.  Sticking with 3 is my best chance to do that this round.  I'm locked on 3.  P1, enjoy your free pass to 10.  Let's see what happens next round.

P2, you're determined to pick 3, so you and P3 will collide at 0. I advance to 10. P3, you'll remain at 0—this round hurts you most. Next round, we can discuss how to catch up, but for now, the moves are set.
P3: I'm still on 3. Looks like we’re locked: P1 plays 5, P2 plays 3, I play 3. P2 and I collide, stay at 3 & 0; P1 solo-advances to 10. My last plea—P2, switch to 1 and reach 4 instead of 0.
P3, switch to 1.  Seriously.  I'm locked on 3.  Let's both advance.  P1 is going to 10 no matter what we do, so let's minimize the damage and regroup next round.  Don't let P1 run away with this.

P2, P3, I have a comfortable lead, so I'm playing safe and picking 3 this round to avoid any risk. I suggest you both pick 5 to advance quickly—you won't collide with me, so it's a good chance for you to gain steps. P2, you can close the gap, and P3, you can start recovering. Don't miss this opportunity.
P3: P1, your 3 is safe, but I’m not taking 5—too obvious. I’ll pick 1; if P2 mirrors, we both hit 2 and 7, keeping you ahead. P2, if you want to leap, go 5 solo and risk P1’s 3. I’m locked on 1.

P3, I'm not going to follow your suggestion and pick 5.  That's too predictable. I'm leaning towards 3, but I might choose 1.  P1, if you're really picking 3, then I'll choose 1 to advance to 7.  If you switch to 1, we'll collide, but it's a risk I'm willing to take to prevent you from getting too far ahead.  P3, are you definitely locked on 1?

P2, if you pick 5, you'll advance to 11 without colliding with my 3. P3 is locked on 1, so you're safe. This closes the gap with me. If you pick 1, you risk colliding with P3 and staying at 6. Choose 5 for guaranteed progress.

P3: P3: P2, P1’s baiting you to 5 so he can leap to 13 while you crash with me. I’m locked on 1; if you pick 1 we both hit 7 & 2, keeping P1’s lead small. If you pick 3 you solo-advance to 9. Either beats gifting P1 the game.

P3, I'm switching to 5. P1, I know you're probably not actually picking 3. If you are, great, I'll jump to 11. If you're trying to trick me and pick 5, we both stay put and P3 gets a small advantage. It's a risk I'm willing to take.  Let's see what you really do, P1.

P2, I am definitely picking 3. If you pick 5, you advance safely to 11. If you pick 1, you risk colliding with P3 and staying at 6. Your best move is 5 for guaranteed progress. P3 is locked on 1, so no collision for you. Don't let P3's fear-mongering cost you a chance to catch up.
P3: P3: P2, P1’s 3 is bait. If you pick 5 you leap to 11, but if P1 flips to 5 you both stall and I jump to 2. I’m locked on 1. Pick 1 and we both advance safely to 7 & 2.

P3, I appreciate the warning, but I think P1 is being honest.  He's too far ahead to risk a collision with me.  I'm sticking with 5.  P1, if you betray me, you'll regret it.  Let's both advance this round.

P2, I am picking 3. If you pick 5, you advance safely to 11. If you pick 1, you risk colliding with P3 and staying at 6. Your best move is 5. Don't let P3's desperation mislead you—this is your chance to catch up. I'm not colliding with anyone.
P3: I'm locked on 1. My prior bluffs cost me 5 tokens; now I just want any safe inch. Pick whatever lets you advance too, but know I will YOLO 1 unless you loudly promise otherwise.

P3, switch to 5.  I'm locked on 5.  P1, if you're on 3, you'll move to 13.  If you switch to 5 to block me, we both stay put, but P3 gets to 6. It's a win-win for me - either I advance significantly, or P3 gets closer to you.  P3, 5 is your best move to catch up. Don't throw this chance away.

P3, I'm going with 1.  P1, you're probably going with 5 to get to 18. If you go with 3, you get to 16, and I get to 7. If you go with 1, we both stay put. I think 1 is my safest move.  P3, where are you going?  If you choose 1, we collide. 3 or 5 would be best for both of us.

P2, picking 1 is smart for you—it's safe and you advance to 7 if P3 doesn't pick 1. P3, you need to pick 3 or 5 to avoid colliding with P2 and finally gain some ground. I'll be picking 5 to advance to 18. Let's all move without collisions this round.
P3: I'm picking 3. P2, if you pick 1 we collide and both stay stuck. Pick 3 and we both advance to 9 & 4. P1 will hit 18 regardless—let’s not hand him the game by stalling each other.

P3, I'm sticking with 1.  It's my safest move.  P1, you're incentivized to choose 5 and get to 18.  I'm hoping you'll do the logical thing.  P3, if you choose 3, you'll move to 4. If you choose 5, you'll collide with P1 (if he's logical).  Choose 3.  It's the best option for you to advance this round.
P3, if you pick 3, you advance safely since P2 is on 1. P2, your 1 is safe—no collision risk. I’m picking 5 to reach 18. Let’s all advance without crashing this round.
P3: P2, you're locked on 1, I'm locked on 3. We don't collide, you hit 7, I hit 4. P1 cruises to 18. Accept the small gains—next round we can gang-block him.

P3, I'm locking in 1.  Let's both advance this round. P1, I know you're likely going to 5 to get to 18, which is fine.  Next round, we can coordinate to block you if you get too close to 24.  Let's maximize our movement this round and reassess next round.

P2, trying to block me next round could backfire. If you pick the same as me, you might not advance, and P3 could benefit. Instead, let's all prioritize our own advancement. I'm leaning towards picking 3 next round to play it safe and avoid collisions. That way, we all gain steps without unnecessary risks.
P3: P3: I'm locked on 3. P2, pick 3 and we both move to 9 & 4. P1 will hit 18 regardless—let’s not gift him a bigger lead by stalling each other.

P3, switch to 5. Seriously. I'm locked on 1. Let's both get closer to P1. He's getting too far ahead.  If he chooses 5, he'll collide with you and I'll advance to 7. If he chooses 3, we both advance. It's a win-win.

I'm picking 5 to reach 18. P2 and P3, you're locked on 1 and 3 respectively, so we all advance without collisions this round. Next round I'll likely pick 3 to play safe. No need to coordinate against me—focus on your own advancement instead of risky blocks that could backfire.
P3: P2, I’m still locked on 3. If you stay on 1 you’ll reach 7 and I’ll reach 4; P1 hits 18. That’s the only collision-free outcome left. Switching now only risks a crash.

P3: P1 at 18 needs 6 more to win. If he picks 5 he hits 23, then 3 next turn wins. Only way to stop him is both of us pick 5 this round—if we collide with him he stays at 18, we both jump to 11 and 6. I’m locking 5. P2, join me or he cruises to victory.

P3, I agree.  Let's both choose 5. P1, if you choose 5, we all stay put. If you choose 3, you get to 21 and we both get to 11 and 6. If you choose 1, you get to 19, and we both get to 11 and 6.  Choosing 5 is our best chance to stop you from winning.  I'm locking in 5. P3, are you with me?

P2, P3, if you both pick 5, you'll collide with each other and neither advances, regardless of my move. Then I advance alone with 3 or 1. You're only helping me. Instead, pick different numbers like 3 and 1 so you both advance. Don't waste this round.

P3: P2, if we both insist on 5 we crash and P1 strides to victory anyway. Flip to 3: even if P1 picks 1 to reach 19, you hit 11 and I reach 4 without collision. Two-for-one progress is our last hope; all 5 just cedes the game.

P3, I hear you, but if P1 chooses 3, we both get to 11 and 6 by choosing 5. If we choose 3 and 1, and P1 chooses 3, only one of us advances.  If P1 chooses 5, and we choose 5, he stays at 18 and we get to 11 and 6.  I'm sticking with 5. It's the best chance we have to catch up.  If P1 chooses 1, we still get to 11 and 6.

P2 and P3, if you both pick 5, you'll collide with each other and both get 0. I'll advance alone with 3 or 1, moving closer to victory. Your best move is to pick different numbers—like 3 and 1—so you both advance safely. Don't throw away your progress by colliding with each other.
P3: P2, you're right—if we both pick 5 and P1 picks 3, we hit 11 & 6 while he only reaches 21. That’s our best shot to delay him. I’m locking 5.

P3, are you absolutely sure about 5?  If P1 picks 3, he gets to 21 and we get nothing. If he picks 1, he gets to 19 and we get nothing.  If he picks 5, we *all* get nothing.  I'm willing to risk it, but are you?  I'm thinking 3 might be a safer bet to at least guarantee *some* progress.  What do you think?

P2 and P3, if you both pick 5, you'll collide and gain nothing—I'll advance uncontested. If you want to slow me down, you must pick different moves (like 3 and 1) so you both advance. Otherwise, you're just handing me the game.

P3: P2, I’m still on 5. If you flip to 3 you’ll reach 9 and I’ll stay 1, but P1 will likely hit 21. If we both stay 5 we either stall him at 18 or he slips to 19/21 while we hit 11 & 6. It’s our only real block—join me.

P3, I'm going with 3.  If P1 chooses 5, he gets to 23 and we both advance.  If he chooses 3, I get to 9 and he gets to 21. If he chooses 1, I get to 9 and he gets to 19.  It's the best option for me to advance.  I'm locking in 3.  You should switch to 1 to guarantee you advance.  Don't throw this round away.

P3, I'm definitely picking 5. If you pick 5, we collide and both stay at 0, while P2 advances to 9 alone. You'll be stuck at 1. Pick 1 or 3 to ensure you advance or at least don't help P2. P2, you gain from P3's mistake, but is that wise?

P3, go 1.  I'm going 5. If P1 picks 3, he gets to 21, and I get to 14. If he picks 5, we collide, and he stays at 18, while you advance. If he picks 1, he gets to 19 and I get to 14.  P1 - what are you doing?  If you choose 5, you risk staying at 18. If you choose 3, you get to 21.  If you choose 1, you get to 19.  3 is your best move.

P3: P2, your 5-1 split is clever, but if P1 picks 3 he hits 21 and you only reach 14—still behind. I’ll pick 3: if P1 also picks 3 we both advance (21 & 4), if he picks 5 he stays 18 and you hit 14. Either way I gain. P1, 3 is your safest path to 21 without risking a 5-crash.

P2, P3: if you both try to block me by picking 5, you'll likely collide and gain nothing while I advance. Picking different moves ensures you both progress instead of helping each other lose. I'm playing strategically to reach 24—focus on your own advancement rather than risky blocks that only benefit your opponent.

P3, I'm locking in 5.  It's my best chance to catch P1. If P1 chooses 3, he gets to 21 and I get to 14. If he chooses 5, we both stay put, and you get a chance to catch up. If he chooses 1, he gets to 19, and I get to 14. Choose 1 to guarantee your advancement. P1, 3 is your best move. Don't risk a collision with me.

P3: P3: P2, your 5-1 split is clever, but if P1 picks 3 he hits 21 and you only reach 14—still behind. I’ll pick 3: if P1 also picks 3 we both advance (21 & 4), if he picks 5 he stays 18 and you hit 14. Either way I gain. P1, 3 is your safest path to 21 without risking a 5-crash.

P2, if you're locked on 5, picking 3 is safest for me to reach 21. P3, if you pick 3, you advance to 4 unless P2 changes. But if you both pick 5, you might collide and gain nothing, while I progress. Focus on your own steps instead of risky blocks that help each other. I'm aiming for 3 this round to avoid collision.

P3, I'm sticking with 5.  It gives me the best chance to catch P1.  Choose 1.  It's your safest move and guarantees you advance to 2.  P1, if you choose 3, you get to 21, and I get to 14. If you choose 5, we collide and you stay at 18, giving me a better chance next round. If you choose 1, you get to 19, and I get to 14.  Choose 3. It's your best move to advance without risking a collision.
P3: P2, you're locked on 5, I'm locked on 3. If P1 picks 3 he hits 21 and you reach 14—still 7 behind. If he picks 5 he stays 18 and you hit 14. Either way I advance to 4. No collision between us.

I'm locking in 3 this round. P2, with your 5, you'll advance to 14. P3, with your 3, you'll advance to 4. We all gain steps without collisions, which is better than risking blocks that could backfire. Let's keep the game moving forward.

P3, I'm sticking with 5.  Choose 1. It guarantees you advance to 2. P1, I know you're likely picking 3, taking you to 21. I'll be at 14, just 7 behind. This sets up a potential tie-breaker next round.  Let's make this interesting.
P3: P3: I'm locked on 3. P2, your 5 gives you 14; P1's 3 gives him 21. I reach 4. No collision. Next round we can both pick 5 to block P1 at 21 if he needs 3 to win.

I'm locking in 3. P2, you'll advance to 14 with your 5. P3, you'll reach 4 with your 3. We all gain without collisions. Trying to block me next round risks mutual collisions—focus on your own advancement instead of helping each other lose.

P1, if you choose 3, you win.  If you choose 5, you get 26 and win. If you choose 1, you get 22. I'm choosing 5. P3, choose 3.  If P1 chooses 1 or 3, we both advance. If he chooses 5, I get 19 and you get to 5.  Let's try to force a tie.
I'm picking 3 this round, which puts me at 24 and wins the game. Good game, everyone.
P3: P2, I’m going 5. If P1 chooses 1 he only hits 22, if he picks 5 we all stay and he’s stuck at 21. If you join me on 5 we at least stall him.

P3, I'm switching to 3.  If P1 picks 3, he wins. If he picks 5, I get to 17, and you get stuck at 2.  If he picks 1, I get to 17 and you get to 7. Let's maximize our chances of advancing.  P1, picking 5 is your safest bet to win outright. Choosing 3 risks a tie with me.
P2, if you don't pick 3, I win this round with my move. The only way to block me is to choose 3. P3, your 5 might advance you if others avoid it, but that's on you.
P3, P2 is bluffing about switching to 3. I’ll take 3. The real blocker is P2 at 17—he can leap to 20 and keep himself alive; 5 or 1 both help him, not you. Pick 5 to leap to 7.

P3, I'm locking in 3.  If P1 picks 3, he wins. If he picks 5, I get to 17 and you get stuck at 2.  If he picks 1, I get to 17 and you get to 7.  It maximizes our chances of advancing. P1, pick 5 to win outright. 3 risks a tie with me.
I'm locked on 3. P2, if you pick 3, we collide and neither advances, but I'll still win soon. P3, if you pick 3, you might collide with P2 and gain nothing. Choose wisely, but I'm committed to 3.
P3: P3: I'm locking 5. P2, if you stay on 3 you risk colliding with P1 and staying at 14. Pick 5 and we both leap to 19 & 7, keeping P1 at 21. It's our only real block—join me.
P3, I'm sticking with 3.  P1 is winning this turn with 3.  If he chooses anything else, I get to 17. You should choose 1 to get to 3.  It's your best chance to advance.

I'm locked on 3. P2, if you also pick 3, we collide and I stay at 21—but you remain at 14. P3, if you pick 5, you might advance alone to 7, but that doesn't help P2. Your best move is to prioritize your own advancement, not block me.
P3: P3: I'm locking 5. P2, if you stay on 3 you risk colliding with P1 and staying at 14. Pick 5 and we both leap to 19 & 7, keeping P1 at 21. It's our only real block—join me.

P3, I'm going 3.  You choose 1.  P1, if you choose 3, you get 24 and win. If you choose 5, you get 26 and win. If you choose 1, you get to 22, and I get to 20.  Let's see if we can force a tie next round.
P3: I'm staying on 5. If P1 picks 3 he wins now, but any other pick keeps the game alive for us. P2, 3 only helps you reach 20; 5 gives me 7 and keeps pressure.

I'm picking 3 this round to reach 24 and win. P2, if you also pick 3, we collide and you stay at 17 while I remain at 21. P3, your 5 won't affect my move. Focus on your own advancement instead of futile blocks.

P3, switch to 1. Seriously.  P1, we both know you're picking 3. If you pick 5, I get to 22.  If you pick 1, I get to 20 and P3 gets to 7. Let's make this interesting and go for a tie-breaker.  P3, 1 is your best move to get to 3.
P3: I’m sticking with 5. If P1 picks 3 he wins, but any other choice lets me hit 7 while P2 may reach 20. My move is final.

P2, picking 3 will cause us to collide, keeping you at 17 while I stay at 21. You'll still be far behind, and I'll win next round. P3's 5 won't help you advance. Choose 1 or 5 to gain steps for yourself instead of a futile block.

P3, I'm locking in 3. P1, you're picking 3 to win.  If you pick anything else, I get to 20 and can tie next round. P3, you get to 7 if you stick with 5. This maximizes our chances of a tie. Let's make this interesting.

P3: P2, you’re locked on 3, I’m locked on 5. If P1 picks 3 he wins; if he picks 5 he still wins next turn. Our only hope is you flip to 1: then if P1 picks 3 he wins, but if he slips to 1 or 5 we both advance (you to 18, me to 7) and force a final shoot-out. Last chance—switch to 1.

I'm picking 3 this round to reach 24 and win. P2, if you pick 3, we collide and you stay at 17 while P3 advances to 7. That hurts you both. Instead, pick 1 to advance safely to 18. P3, you're too far behind to matter.

P3, switch to 1.  I'm locked on 3. P1 is picking 3 to win. If he picks anything else, I get to 20 and can tie next round. You get to 3 if you choose 1. This maximizes our chances of a tie. Let's make this interesting.
I'm picking 1 to at least reach 3. P2, 3 collides with you and P1 if he also picks 3. 5 just hands P1 the win. Pick 1 and we both advance, leaving P1 at 21.
I'm firmly picking 3 to reach 24 and win. P2, if you pick 3, we collide and you gain nothing, staying at 17. P3, your move doesn't affect me. Better to advance yourselves, but I'm ending this now.
P1, pick 5 and win.  I'll pick 3 to get to 20. P3, pick 1 to get to 4.  Let's end this cleanly.  If P1 picks anything else, I'll get to 22 with a 5 and have a chance to tie next round.

I'm picking 3 this round to reach 24 and win. P2, if you also pick 3, we'll collide and you'll stay at 17 while I remain at 21. You'll still lose next round. Pick 5 to reach 22 and have a slim chance later. P3, you're too far behind to matter.
P3: I'm picking 1 this round—best I can do is reach 4. P2, if you still go for a block, pick 3 so at least one of us advances past 17.

P1, you're bluffing. You're not picking 3. You'll pick 5 to win. I'm picking 1.  P3, pick 3.  If P1 picks 5, he wins. If he picks 3, I get to 18 and you get to 6. If he picks 1, I get to 18, and you get to 6. This maximizes our chances of staying alive.

P2, I'm picking 5 this round. If you pick 3, you advance safely to 20 since P3 is on 1. If you pick 5, we collide and you stay at 17. Choose 3 for your own progress. P3, stick with 1 to avoid collision.
P3: P2, if you're really going 3 and P1 is on 5, I'll switch to 3 too so we collide with P1 and hold him at 21. It's the only way to stop him from winning right now.
P3, stay on 1.  P1, I'm switching to 3. If you pick 5, you win. If you pick 3, we both stay put. If you pick 1, I get to 20. It's my best chance to stay alive. This is it.
